I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  requested  technical 
assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to conduct a study on nonpoint 
source  (NPS)  pollution  monitoring  and  measurement,  and  to  develop  an  NPS  pollution 
management framework.1 The TA is in the PRC’s country operations business plan, 2011–2013 
and was in the standby category in ADB’s TA pipeline for 2011, but was upgraded to firm 
category based on government’s request. ADB fielded a reconnaissance mission to Beijing in 
April 2011 and held discussions with the Ministry of Environmental Protection (MEP) to clarify 
and agree on the scope, impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, and 
financing arrangements for the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. The 
TA provides timely support to the PRC’s transition towards more sustainable development and a 
harmonious society. It is also in line with ADB’s Strategy 2020,2 which aims to promote inclusive 
growth and environmentally sustainable growth.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Water resource scarcity is a serious constraint on the PRC’s sustainable development. 
The country’s annual per capita water availability of 1,800–2,200 cubic meters is about one-
quarter of the world average; the northern part of the PRC is below the water scarcity threshold 
of 1,000 cubic meters per capita. Severe water pollution exacerbates water scarcity in the PRC. 
A report by MEP on the state of the environment in 2009 found that more than 40% of the 408 
sections along the major PRC rivers where water quality is monitored had unsafe water for 
human consumption and about 18% had unsafe water for any use. Water quality has not 
improved significantly with rapid economic growth.4 
 
3.  Sources of water pollution can be divided into two broad categories: point sources and 
nonpoint sources. Point sources of water pollution, such as large industrial facilities or sewage 
treatment plants, emit pollutants into a water body from a fixed, readily identifiable point. In 
contrast, emissions from nonpoint sources are geographically diffused and temporally stochastic. 
Major nonpoint sources of water pollution include agrochemical (fertilizer, pesticide, herbicide) 
runoff, discharges from animal or aquatic production activities, and soil erosion. These are 
mostly concentrated in rural areas. 
 
4.    While the government has made advances in controlling industrial and domestic point 
sources of water pollution, NPS pollution has become a growing challenge nationwide. The first 
national survey of pollution sources carried out by the MEP between 2007 and 2010 concluded 
that NPS pollution accounted for about 44% of chemical oxygen demand, 55% of nitrogen, and 
67% of phosphorous discharges.5 Runoff from farms was the second-largest source of nitrogen 
discharges after domestic wastewater. Intensive animal husbandry was found to be the largest 
source  of  phosphorous  discharges.  Both  nitrogen  and  phosphorous discharges  contributed 
directly to the pervasive eutrophication of the water in the PRC. Therefore, NPS pollution will 
have to be dealt with effectively to bring water pollution under control.

5.   The  nature  of  nonpoint  sources  determines  the  difficulties  and  challenges  in  NPS 
pollution control. First, it is extremely difficult to monitor and measure emissions from nonpoint 
sources, although monitoring and measuring NPS discharges are the bases for pollution control 
instruments such as the emissions trading program. In developed countries, emission proxies 
through  measuring  inputs  (e.g.,  fertilizer  use),  agricultural  practices,  and  land  use  and 
performance  (e.g.,  annual  soil  loss)  were  often  developed  and  used  to  estimate  pollutant 
discharges through sophisticated models. To obtain accurate estimates of NPS emissions, 
these monitoring and measurement methods, and the associated models, must be localized. 
This requires a tremendous amount of inputs from research and field work, as well as an 
enormous amount of data. Data availability, and implementation costs and capacity, have to be 
taken into account in developing countries. Therefore, developing countries such as the PRC 
must  develop  feasible  and  cost-effective  methods  to  monitor  and  measure  NPS  pollution 
emissions.  
 
6.   Second, agricultural runoff is the major component of NPS pollution largely because of 
the choices and behavior of many small farmers. The main goal of the farmers is to increase 
agricultural production in the most cost-effective way, which suggests increasing dependence 
on fertilizer and choosing low-priced, single-ingredient fertilizers over high-priced, compound 
fertilizers. With income growth, domestic demand for livestock products has been increasing 
quickly, which has led to a dramatic rise in livestock production in rural PRC. While this has 
increased rural incomes, the PRC’s livestock industry is characterized by numerous small and 
medium-sized producers with few incentives to preserve the environment. Therefore, unlike 
point-source regulations, NPS pollution control must address many small polluters with limited 
income-earning  potential.  It  is  essential  to  understand  their  incentives  and  choices  before 
designing and implementing sound policy interventions. Moreover, NPS pollution management 
needs to interact and be coordinated with policies in other sectors, such as agriculture and 
water resources, which significantly affect the polluters’ decision making.    
 
7.   Third, while a range of policy instruments are available for NPS pollution control, it is 
unclear which ones—individually or in combination—will work effectively and efficiently in a 
developing country. The potential instruments include direct regulations (e.g., mandatory use of 
certain practices), economic incentives (e.g., taxes and subsidies, eco-compensation), liability 
rules,  and  education  campaigns.  Based  on  the  experiences  and  evidence  accumulated  in 
developed countries, critical analysis is needed to demonstrate the feasibility, constraints, and 
effectiveness of different instruments for NPS pollution management in the PRC. Since the 
polluters  are  numerous  small  farmers  with  low  incomes,  an  NPS  pollution  management 
framework also needs to achieve a balance between environmental preservation and economic 
development. Attention should be paid to those policies and arrangements that will benefit the 
farmers in the long term, directly or indirectly, while improving the quality of the environment. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
8.  The TA will address the technical and policy challenges of NPS pollution control in the 
PRC. Advances in NPS pollution monitoring and measurement will provide a solid technical 
basis for NPS pollution management. An NPS pollution management framework that fits the 
PRC’s situation and balances the benefits of environmental improvement and development 
needs will contribute to NPS pollution control and sustainable development in rural areas. The 
TA will build on the findings and achievements of a previous ADB TA for the Study of Control 
and Management of Rural Nonpoint Source Pollution, which produced a draft regulation on 
pollution prevention and control on livestock production and a medium-term action plan for rural

3 
NSP pollution control.6 Further, the previous TA recognizes an integrated approach that aims to 
change farmers’ behavior as the best way to control and reduce NSP pollution. The proposed 
TA  will  follow  up  these  policy  recommendations  and  develop  an  evidence-based  and 
implementable NPS pollution management framework. 
 
9.  With the available resources, a case study of one of the key watersheds is advisable. 
The  findings  can  then  be  scaled  up  to  the  national  level.  Chao  Lake  is  the  fifth-largest 
freshwater lake in the PRC with a surface area of 776 square kilometers and lake basin area of 
13,350 square kilometers. The lake is the major source of drinking water for 6.3 million residents 
in  the  surrounding  cities  and  towns,  and  a  source  of  water  for  irrigation  and  industrial 
production.  Chao  Lake  basin  has  been  severely  polluted  since  the  1990s.  NPS  pollution 
discharge resulting from the intensification of agricultural practices and the dramatic increase in 
livestock  production  is one  of the major  challenges.  Chao  Lake  is  one  of the  operational 
priorities of ADB in the PRC. A loan project that is under processing, the proposed Anhui Chao 
Lake  Environmental  Rehabilitation  Project,  aims  to  introduce  an  integrated  approach  to 
addressing Chao Lake pollution, including NPS pollution. Another reason for choosing Chao 
Lake for the TA is to enable resource sharing and promote efficiencies. Using Chao Lake as the 
TA  project’s  case  study  may  contribute to  the  loan  project  by  developing  and testing  the 
methodology  for  NPS  pollution  monitoring  and  measurement  through  data  and  knowledge 
sharing. The loan project may also help the TA project by providing efficient administrative 
support from the project management office. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The TA will contribute to a reduced NPS pollution in key lakes and reservoirs with 
emissions of ammonia nitrogen decreased by 15% from 2010 levels by 2018. The outcome of 
the  TA  will  be  improved  NPS  pollution  management  and  control,  with  the  draft  NPS 
management framework adopted in one MEP management notice on NPS pollution by 2014. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA’s main outputs are: (i) a comprehensive review of international practices and 
experiences in NPS pollution control is conducted; (ii) an in-depth technical study on NPS 
pollution monitoring and measurement is conducted; (iii) a draft NPS pollution management 
framework for key lakes and reservoirs is prepared; and (iv) a knowledge product identifying the 
causes of NPS pollution and discussing challenges in and policy recommendations for NPS 
pollution control is prepared. 
 
12.   Key  activities  to  achieve  the  outputs  are  the  following:  (i)  review  literature  on 
international practices and experiences in NPS pollution control, focusing on the institutional, 
economic, and environmental contexts for applying the experiences, costs, and benefits of 
different  approaches;  (ii)  analyze  existing  NPS  pollution  monitoring  and  measurement 
techniques and schemes with respect to their application contexts and costs and benefits, 
developing a methodology to model NPS pollution discharge that would be feasible and cost-
effective in the PRC, and test the methodology by calibrating a model to the Chao Lake basin 
(or sub-basin); (iii) collect detailed data on existing policies and institutions for NPS pollution 
management,  agricultural  practices  by  farm  households,  and  waste  treatment  of  livestock 
producers through access to databases, site visits, focus group discussions, and household

surveys; (iv) prepare the draft management framework based on a comprehensive literature 
review, careful data analysis, and wide consultation with stakeholders; and (v) prepare and 
publish a paper based on these outputs (para. 11) and disseminate the paper through internal 
and external workshops and conferences. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $480,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The  government  will  provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff time, access to data sources, assistance to 
field trips, office space, use of facilities, and logistical support. The cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.   The Department of Pollution Control of the MEP will be the executing agency for the TA. 
A project management office will be set up within the MEP and will be responsible for day-to-
day TA activities, including overseeing the TA consultants’ work plans, reviewing their outputs, 
and coordinating with the consultants on the preparation of the workshops. TA implementation 
will be closely coordinated with other government agencies such as the Ministry of Agriculture 
and the Ministry of Water Resources, as well as local governments in Anhui province. 
 
15.  The  TA  project  will  be  implemented  over  24  months,  tentatively  scheduled  from  1 
January 2012 to 31 December 2013. The TA requires an estimated 49 person-months of 
consulting services, comprising 9 person-months of international consultants and 40 person-
months of national consultants. The consultants will include an international NPS  pollution 
specialist and team leader, an international water pollution management specialist, a national 
environmental policy specialist and deputy team leader, a national NPS pollution specialist, a 
national  water  pollution management  specialist,  a  national  agriculture  specialist,  a  national 
agricultural policy specialist, and a national environmental economist. The outline terms of 
reference for consulting services is in Appendix 3.  
 
16.  ADB  will engage the consultants through a consulting firm,  in accordance with the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time), using the quality- 
and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10. The simplified technical 
proposal approach will be used to assess the qualifications of the bidding firms because the 
study  involves  complicated  methodology  and  needs  to  be  well  planned  and  coordinated. 
Equipment for research and field investigation, including computers, cameras, and recorders, 
will be procured following ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time), 
and will be turned over to the Department of Pollution Control upon completion of the TA 
activities.  The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010 as amended from time to time). 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
17.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $480,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Nonpoint Source Pollution Control in 
Catchment Areas, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  project  will  undertake  four  interrelated  tasks:  (i)  a 
comprehensive review of international practices and experiences in nonpoint source (NPS) 
pollution control; (ii) an in-depth technical study on NPS pollution monitoring and measurement 
covering existing practices in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), challenges and difficulties, 
available technological and institutional options, cost and benefit analysis of the options, and 
recommendations;  (iii)  a  draft  NPS  pollution  management  framework  for  key  lakes  and 
reservoirs,  which  includes  goals,  approaches,  constraints,  resources  needed,  institutional 
arrangements, and interaction with relevant policies; and (iv) a knowledge product addressing 
the causes of NPS pollution and discussing challenges in and policy recommendations for NPS 
pollution control. 
 
2.  Two  international  consultants  (9  person-months)  and  six  national  consultants  (40 
person-months)  with  expertise  in  NPS  pollution  control,  water  resource  and  pollution 
management, environmental economics and policy, and agricultural economics and policy will 
be  engaged for this TA.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  select  and  engage the 
consultants through a consulting firm in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time), using the quality- and cost-based selection 
method with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10. The simplified technical proposal approach will be 
used because the TA requires highly technical knowledge as well as innovative efforts  to 
address a long-standing challenge, to which few effective solutions have been made available 
for the executing agency.  
 
A.  Team  Leader  and  Nonpoint  Source  Pollution  Specialist (international, 6 person-
months)  
3.  The team leader and NPS pollution specialist should have a post-graduate degree or 
equivalent and 15 or more years of experience in the relevant fields. Demonstrated project-
related experience in the PRC is desirable. The consultant will be responsible for the final 
outputs of the study as well as for the daily coordination and supervision of the TA team. 
Specifically, the consultant will 
 
(i)  develop the detailed study framework in consultation with the executing agency, 
key stakeholders, and other experts;  
(ii)  develop outlines of the inception, interim, and final TA reports; 
(iii)  compile and finalize the TA reports, including  the inception, interim, and final 
reports and their revised versions; 
(iv)  manage and ensure timely implementation of TA activities, including the overall 
coordination of the inputs from team members; and conduct the inception, interim, 
finalization, and dissemination workshop; 
(v)  conduct  a  literature  review  of  international  practices  and  experiences  in  NPS 
pollution control with the water pollution management specialist (international), 
taking into account the results and findings of a related ADB TA for the Study of 
Control and Management of Rural Nonpoint Source Pollution;1 
(vi)  lead the study on NPS pollution monitoring and measurement techniques, explore 
an  appropriate  modeling  approach  to  identify  and  measure  NPS  pollution

D.  Nonpoint Source Pollution Specialist (national, 6 person-months) 
 
6.  The NPS specialist should have a post-graduate degree or equivalent and 15 or more 
years of experience in the relevant fields. Demonstrated experience and knowledge directly 
related to the Chao Lake basin is desirable. The consultant will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  provide substantial inputs on the development and refining of a study framework 
and outlines of TA reports;  
(ii)  provide  substantial  inputs  on  the  study  of  NPS  pollution  monitoring  and 
measurement techniques; 
(iii)  explore an appropriate modeling approach to identify and measure NPS pollution 
discharges, and examine ways to determine model specifications and coefficients 
for the Chao Lake basin, with the team leader and other team members;  
(iv)  provide inputs on the development of an NPS pollution management framework in 
the PRC with the team leader’s guidance; 
(v)  participate in field trips to Chao Lake; 
(vi)  provide inputs on the TA reports, including the inception, interim, and final reports 
and their revised versions; and 
(vii)  conduct other related work assigned by the team leader. 
 
E.  Water Pollution Management Specialist (national, 6 person-months) 
 
7.  The  water  pollution  management  specialist  should  have  a  post-graduate  degree  or 
equivalent and 10 or more years of experience in the relevant fields. Demonstrated experience 
and  knowledge  directly  related  to  the  Chao  Lake  basin  is  desirable.  The  consultant  will 
undertake the following tasks:

H.  Environmental Economist (national, 7 person-months) 
 
10.  The environmental economist should have a post-graduate degree or equivalent and 10 
or more years of experience in the relevant fields. The consultant will undertake the following 
tasks: 
 
(i)  provide substantial inputs on the development and refining of a study framework 
and outlines of TA reports;  
(ii)  conduct a literature review and analysis on the market mechanisms in dealing with 
NPS pollution, including water quality trading, payment for ecological services, 
taxes, and subsidies; 
(iii)  design  and  conduct  household  surveys,  with  the  agricultural  policy  specialist, 
aiming to understand farmers’ behavior and choices related to NPS pollution, such 
as the purchase and application of fertilizer and pesticides, and waste treatment in 
livestock production; 
(iv)  assess the costs and benefits of various technical and policy instruments in NPS 
pollution control, taking Chao Lake basin as a representative case; 
(v)  provide inputs on the NPS pollution management framework with a focus on the 
application of market mechanisms;  
(vi)  participate in field trips to Chao Lake; 
(vii)  provide inputs on the TA reports, including the inception, interim, and final reports 
and their revised versions; and 
(viii)  conduct other related work assigned by the team leader. 
 
I.  Reporting 
11.  The consulting team will submit the following reports: (i) an inception TA report within 1 
month  after  mobilization,  (ii)  a  revised  inception  report  within  15  days  after  the  inception 
workshop, (iii) an interim TA report within 7 months after mobilization or 1 month before the 
interim workshop, (iv) a revised interim report within 1 month after the interim workshop, (v) a 
draft final report within 13 months after mobilization or 1 month before the finalization workshop, 
(vi) a final report 2 months after the finalization workshop or at the conclusion of the TA, (vii) a 
draft knowledge product 13 months after mobilization, and (viii) a final knowledge product at the 
conclusion of the TA. The revised inception report, revised interim report, the final report, and 
the  final  knowledge  product  should  incorporate  or  address  comments  from  the  executing 
agency, relevant government agencies, the ADB, and other invited reviewers. All reports will be 
submitted in English and Chinese languages—six copies each to the executing agency and two 
copies each plus one electronic copy to ADB. The reports will be published in both languages 
online.
